data.title: Concert Chronology / Gigography (I)
data.text:
1979

The year in which the future band members first start making music together.

1979

DE Berlin-Schöneberg,Goltzstrasse 37,Eisengrau shop-flat.

Photo: Credit Sabine Schwabroh. Google-street view circa 2009.

Note: In June 1979 Gudrun Gut, Bettina Köster and Claudia Skoda open a clothes and design shop at Goltzstrasse 37. The name Eisengrau/Irongrey is taken from the colour of the paint pots which were left in the shop by the former tenant. The old paint is used to paint the shelves. The clothes they design are mainly grey of colour. By end of 1979 the shop is transferred to Blixa, who starts selling tapes from the shop, whilst the girls keep on selling their clothes and design. Wolfgang Müller [Die Tödliche Doris] uses the place to sell copies of his fanzine and the shop becomes a scene-hangout. A.o. Ben Becker, Fetish, Alex Hacke, Padeluun, etc.. show up frequently. After some time Blixa's other shop-flat at the Langenscheidtstrasse is no longer used.

1980

The year in which the band is officialy founded. Recording and release of the "Für den Untergang" 7" and several live tapes.

They only play a handful of live dates in Berlin with regular equipment and sound very much like a 'real' band.

At the end of the year they will play in Hamburg (their first concert outside of Berlin). Line-up #1a (DE, Berlin: March 1980 - May 1980):

Blixa Bargeld (guitar, vocals)/ N.U. Unruh (drums)/ Beate Bartel (bass) and Gudrun Gut (synth)

Mar-80

DE Berlin-Schöneberg,Eisengrau shop (@ Goltzstrasse 37)

Note: Rehearsing for the upcoming first concert.

01-Apr-80

DE Berlin-Wilmersdorf,Diskothek Moon (@ Bundesallee 194)

Setlist: Gier (a.k.a. Tanz Debil)/ Hören-Gehört werden (a.k.a. Sprachlos)/ Atomarer Walzer/ Atomarer Walzer-Nach mir kommst nichts mehr/ Frishes Blut für Berlin/ Valium(*).

Flyer: Reproduction of flyer taken from "Nur was nicht ist/ No Beauty" book.

Note: Their first concert. About 50 people attend. They perform improvised music to Super-8 films and sound very much like a 'real' band with Blixa Bargeld on vocals and guitar, Beate Bartel on bass, Gudrun Gut on Korg MS-20 synthesiser and N.U. Unruh on real drums. Gudrun and Beate were at the time also in Mania D. The concert was recorded by the band and later sold as a cassette in Blixa's 'Eisengrau' shop. All tracks are available on the "Einstürzende Neubauten (Live In Kunstkopfstereo)" cassette, except (*) on the "Chaos-> Sehnsucht/ Energie" cassette.

12-Apr-80

DE Berlin-Kreuzberg,Merhaba-SO36 (@ Oranienstraße 190)

[with Alvaro]

Setlist: Sendezeichen (a.k.a. Alles)/ Für den Untergang (a.k.a. Kriegstanz or Stahlversion)/ Gewaltige Gefühle/ Chaos - Frishes Blut für Berlin(*)/ Sehnsucht.

Flyer: Scan of flyer.

Note 1: Their second concert. Bettina Köster (then in Mania D.) played sax on (*). Recorded by the band and available on the "Chaos-> Sehnsucht/Energie" cassette.

Note 2: SO36, a former cinema, turned into a Penny discount super market in 1967, opened as a music venue on 11-Aug-78 by new owners Achim Schächtele, Klaus-Dieter Brennecke and Andreas Rohè. By Jan-79 artist Martin Kippenberger took over Brennecke's share. All three sold the place in summer of '79 to Hilal Kurutan (from Turkish origin), who reopened it as Merhaba ("Good day" in Turkish) SO36 in Nov-79, booking concerts together with Michael Schäumer, Michael Voigt (Monogam Records/People's Records) and Burkhardt Seiler (Zensor records) as well as organising Turkish events, until end of Mar-83, when building regulations forced Hilal to shut the venue down. It was sold/reopened/refurbished several times throughout the next decades and is still active to this day. (More reading in the brilliant "SO36  1978 bis heute" bi-lingual book, Ventil Verlag, 2016).

May-80

DE Release of the "Einstürzende Neubauten(Live In Kunstkopfstereo)" cassette on Eisengrau

May-80

DE Berlin,Alex Kögler's Kunstgalerie

Note: Their third concert. In 1981, Alex Kögler opened the Risiko bar (@ Yorckstrasse 48). He died in August 2014 at the age of 56.

10-May-80

DE Berlin-Schöneberg,a place on Crellestrasse

Setlist: Alles/ Für den Untergang/ Gewaltige Gefühle/ Sehnsucht/ Chaos.

Note: Their fourth concert. With Chrislo Haas [DAF, Liaisons Dangereuses] instead of Gudrun Gut and possibly also with Susä Hobeck (who used to be in a pre-Neubauten band with Blixa, N.U. & Bettina Köster). Beate Bartel's last concert with Neubauten. Together with Gudrun Gut she focusses on their own band, Mania D.

Line-up #1b (DE, Berlin: June 1980 - April 1981):

Blixa Bargeld (guitar, vocals) and N.U. Unruh (drums)

01-Jun-80

DE Berlin-Friedenau,Underpass pillar,band rehearsal room.

Blixa Bargeld and N.U. Unruh record "Stahlversion" (first 7" single B-side, a version of "Für den Untergang") and the "Stahlmusik" cassette album.

Photo: Credit Wolfgang Müller [Tödliche Doris], taken from "Hör mit Schmerzen", a book by Klaus Maeck [Rip Off].

Note 1: The space was 1.4 metres high, 5 metres in width and 50 metres in length and made out of steel. Pocket torches were used to lit the place and a Telefunken Bajazzo transistor radio was used as amplifier. The session was taped with an ordinary cassette recorder. Not to be confused with the recording of the "Stahlmusik" video at the same place, but in April 1981.

Note 2: "The rehearsal/practice room of Einstürzende Neubauten, lies "Unter-Tage" [underpass], half an hour from the last bus connection, directly under a very busy motorway in the south-western part [of Berlin] under the north-eastern pillar of a motorway bridge." (translated from "Geniale Dilletanten', a book edited by Wolfgang Müller [Tödliche Doris]).

Note 3: Exact location is where Saarstraße crosses the Autobahn (A103), at the Zehlendorf junction. The plaque (visible in the "Liebeslieder" film) was a mockup made for the film. They removed it after the filming, and now it is at Andrew's place.

Jun-80

DE Release of the "Chaos-> Sehnsucht/Energie" cassette on Eisengrau.

12-Jul-80

DE Berlin-Steglitz,Jazzkeller (@ Breitenbachplatz 8)

Sep-80

DE Release of the "Für den Untergang/Stahlversion" 7" single on Monogam Records.

Oct-80

DE Release of the "Stahlmusik" cassette on Eisengrau.

25-Nov-80

DE Berlin-Schöneberg,Rosa von Praunheim's apartment

Setlist: Amongst others: Wir können nicht spielen.

Photo: Taken from the "Liebeslieder" video.

Note: With Alex von Borsig (a.k.a. Alexander Hacke) on bass. N.U. Unruh still on real drums. Birthday party for film director Rosa von Praunheim. Excerpt available on the "Liebeslieder" video.

27-Dec-80

DE Hamburg,Markthalle (@ Klosterwall 11),Zick Zack-Neue Musik festival

[with Wirtschaftswunder, Die Radierer and Abwärts and more]

Setlist: soundcheck/ Zuckendes Fleisch/ Leben ist Illegal/ (Wir sind) Gut(mit dem Kopf an die Wand)/ Musik ist Macht-Magie/ Für den Untergang.

Poster: Photo of poster.

Note: Festival organised by Alfred Hilsberg (Zick Zack records label). Their first concert outside of Berlin. With Alex von Borsig (a.k.a. Alexander Hacke) joining N.U. Unruh on drums. They decide to play after (local band) Abwärts, because they were afraid the violent Hamburg punks would beat them up (like they did with the other non-Hamburg bands Wirtschaftswunder and Die Radierer). Most people left after Abwärts. At this concert Blixa and FM Einheit [a.k.a. Frank Martin Strauss, then in Abwärts] meet for the first time.

1981

The year in which FM Einheit and Mark Chung join. Recording and release of the "Kalte Sterne" EP and "Kollaps" album.

Their first tour ("Die Berliner Krankheit") of Germany.

20-Mar-81

DE Berlin-Kreuzberg,Merhaba-SO36 (@ Oranienstraße 190)

[with MDK, Glenn Branca Band, the dB's and Lee Ranaldo]

Setlist: Hören/ Für den Untergang/ ?/ Chaos/ Hiroshima/ We will rock you.

Photo: Credit Norbert Bauer.

Note: Most likely with FM Einheit on Casio synth.

Apr-81

DE Berlin-Friedenau,Underpass pillar,band rehearsal room. Recording "Stahlmusik" 20mins video. Filmed by Albrecht Metzger. Not to be confused with the "Stahlmusik" cassette album recorded at the same spot on 01-Jun-80.

Photo: Taken from "Liebeslieder" DVD.

Note: Exact location, see 01-Jun-80 entry above.

Line-up #2a (DE, Berlin: April 1981 - August 1981):

Blixa Bargeld (guitar, vocals)/ N.U. Unruh (drums)/ FM Einheit (percussion) and (sometimes) Mark Chung (bass)

28-Apr-81

DE Hamburg,Markthalle (@ Klosterwall 11)

[with Malaria!, Frieder Butzmann and Kosmonautentraum]

Setlist: Schiess euch ins Blut/ ? /? /Untergangstanz (aka Stahlversion)/ Zuckendes Fleisch-Sehnsucht.

Photo: Credit © Anno Dittmer.

Ticket: Photo of ticket.

Poster: Photo of poster.

Note: 2nd concert in Hamburg. Alex von Borsig joins for this concert. "Untergangstanz" available on the "Alles was irgendwie nützt" 2CD (on which it is listed as 24-Aug-81).

08-May-81

DE Berlin-Schöneberg,Risiko bar (@ Yorckstrasse 48)

[with Die Ich's]

Flyer: Xerox of flyer.

Note: They perform in 2 rooms of the small bar at the same time. Blixa runs back and forth between the 2 rooms and shouts the lyrics into the stunned audience members' ears. Mark Chung (then still in Abwärts) joins for this concert on bass.

15-Jul-81

DE Bochum,Spektrum

Setlist: a.o. Sehnsucht

Flyer: Xerox of flyer.

Note: Above track available on the "Live (aufnahmen 07/81 bis 02/82)" cassette album.

28-Jul-81

DE Release of the "Kalte Sterne" double 7" single on (Alfred Hilsberg's) Zick Zack records label.

Line-up #2b (DE, Berlin: September 1981 - March 1983):

Blixa Bargeld (guitar and vocals)/ N.U. Unruh (drums)/ FM Einheit (percussion)/ Mark Chung (bass)

& Alex Hacke (live sound mixing and hanging around)

04-Sep-81

DE Berlin,Tempodrom (large circus tent @ Potsdamer Platz)

Grosse Untergangs-show/Festival der Genialer Dilletanten

[with Gudrun Gut & Blixa Bargeld, Die Tödliche Doris and many more..]

Setlist: Einstürzende Neubauten: Kollaps.

Flyer: Scan of flyer.

Poster: Photo of poster.

Note: Four day festival, "Bild & Ton im Tempdrom", 27/28-August and 4/5 September. Also performing were Kriegsschauplatz Tempodrom/ Nekropolis-Die Unbekannten / Wir und das Menschliche e.V. (Frieder Butzmann and Alex Kögler)/ Leben und Arbeiten/ Die Tödliche Doris/ Gudrun Gut & Blixa Bargeld/ Vroammm!/ Drei Mädels & Das Meer (Ulla, Beatrice, Gudrun Gut & Alex von Borsig or Alex Kögler)/ Sprung aus den Wolken (Kiddy Citny)/ Sentimentale Jugend (Christiane F. & Alex von Borsig) and Din A Testbild.

A festival organised by Blixa Bargeld, Wolfgang Müller [Die Tödliche Doris] and Mabel Ascheneller, and presented by Wieland Speck. A video was made available (only for rent) from Speck-Productions, but remained largely unseen until it was transferred to DVD in 2005 and properly released (as part of a box with CD/2LP and booklet) by Vinyl-On-Demand. Also available on the "Berliner Dillettanten" bootleg tape.

09-Sep-81

DE Berlin-Kreuzberg,Merhaba-SO36 (@ Oranienstraße 190)

[with Malaria!, Neonbabies and Tempo]

Ticket: Photo of ticket, reproduced in "SO36 1978 bis heute", book (Ventil Verlag, 2016)

12-Sep-81

DE Berlin,Tempodrom (large circus tent @ Potsdamer Platz)

Rock Against Junk II-Festival

[with Theatre of Hate]

Setlist: a.o. Krieg in den Städten (a.k.a. Steh auf Berlin)(*)/ Mit Schmerzen hören-Negativ Nein/ Kollaps(*).

Note: All above tracks available on the "Live In Berlin 1981" tape. (*)released on the "Das Abendprogramm" V/A compilation album.

Sep-81

DE Release of the "Stahlmusik" VHS video tape on (Klaus Maeck's) Rip Off label.

05-Oct-81

DE Release of the "Kollaps" album on (Alfred Hilsberg's) Zick Zack records label.

28-Oct-81

DE Stuttgart,Mausefalle

[with MDK + Sprung aus den Wolken]

Review 1: Xerox taken from Stuttgarter Nachrichten 04-Nov-81.

Review 2: Xerox taken from Stuttgarter Zeitung Nov-81.

Note: Start of the 'Die Berliner Krankheit' tour. Their first tour of Germany.

30-Oct-81

DE Freiburg im Breisgau,Arche

[with MDK + Sprung aus den Wolken]

Photo: Photo of live cassette from the Neubauten archives.

Note: 'Die Berliner Krankheit' tour. Recorded by the band (but not released).

31-Oct-81

DE Wiesbaden,Wartburg Music Hall

[with MDK + Sprung aus den Wolken]

Setlist: Tanz Debil/ Steh auf Berlin(a.k.a. Krieg in den Städten)/ Negativ Nein/ Pygmaën/ Bakterien für euere Seele/ Einsame Wölfin/ Sehnsucht/ Kollaps/ Für den Untergang/ Skorbut-Hör mit Schmerzen.

Ticket: Scan of ticket.

Note: 'Die Berliner Krankheit' tour. "Sehnsucht" and "Kollaps" available on the "Alles was irgendwie nützt" 2CD.

01-Nov-81

DE Neuss,Okie Dokie

[with MDK + Sprung aus den Wolken]

Photo: Credit © Richard Gleim (a.k.a. ar/gee gleim).

Note: 'Die Berliner Krankheit' tour.

03-Nov-81

DE Köln,Stollwerck

[with MDK + Sprung aus den Wolken]

Review: Scan of review, taken from Spex 11/81.

Note: 'Die Berliner Krankheit' tour. In 1839, Franz Stollwerck opened a factory in Cologne, producing cough bonbons. By 1860 the production was extended by chocolate, marzipan and gingerbread. The factory was operational until the late 1970's. In 1980 the derelict Stollwerck was occupied and throughout the 80's used as a cultural centre by "Pallazzo Schoko and Regenbogenhaus" organisation.

05-Nov-81

DE Kiel,-

[with MDK + Sprung aus den Wolken]

06-Nov-81

DE Osnabrück,Hyde Park

[with MDK + Sprung aus den Wolken]

Ad: Scan of ad, taken from Spex 10/81.

Note: 'Die Berliner Krankheit' tour.

07-Nov-81

DE Münster,Jovel

[with MDK + Sprung aus den Wolken]

Setlist: Krieg In Den Städten (a.k.a. Steh Auf Berlin)(*)/ Bakterien Für Eure Seele- Schwarz- Negativ Nein- Einsame Wölfin/ Hirnsäge/ U-Haft Muzak/ Sehnsucht/ Kollaps (*).

Ad: Scan of ad, taken from Tip 23/81.

Note: 'Die Berliner Krankheit' tour. This concert was partially documented on the "Die Berliner Krankheit" video (1981) by Klaus Maeck & Norbert Meissner. (*) tracks available on video.

08-Nov-81

DE Hof (in Oberfranken),Alter Bahnhof

[with MDK + Sprung aus den Wolken]

Poster: Photo of poster.

Photo: Photos by Joachim Hertrich.

10-Nov-81

DE Hannover,Diskothek Rotation

[with MDK + Sprung aus den Wolken]

Setlist: Einsame Wölfin/ Tanz Debil/ Bakterien für euere Seele/ Krieg in den Städten/ Zuckendes Fleisch/ Tageslicht Ertragen (a.k.a. Leben unter der Erde)/ Energie-Sehnsucht/ Kollaps.

Poster: Scan of 'Berliner Krankheit' tour poster, reproduced in "SO36 1978 bis heute", book (Ventil Verlag, 2016).

Review: Scan of review, taken from Schädelspalter 11/81.

Note: 'Die Berliner Krankheit' tour. Moved from the 12th.

11-Nov-81

DE Bielefeld,Titanic (former Diskothek Gurke)

[with MDK + Sprung aus den Wolken]

Ad: Scan of ad, taken from fanzine "Schreckensmomente Im Leben Eines Heino Fans" # 1981 November n°1 .

Review: Scan of review, taken from fanzine "Schreckensmomente Im Leben Eines Heino Fans" # 1981 December n°2 .

Note: 'Die Berliner Krankheit' tour.

13-Nov-81

DE Hamburg,Markthalle (@ Klosterwall 11)

[with MDK + Sprung aus den Wolken]

Ticket: Scan of ticket.

Review: Xerox taken from Taz Hamburg Nov-81.

Note: 'Die Berliner Krankheit' tour.

14-Nov-81

DE Berlin-Kreuzberg,SO 36 (@ Oranienstraße 190)

[with MDK + Sprung aus den Wolken + Die Tödliche Doris]

Setlist: Sehnsucht/ Steh auf Berlin(a.k.a. Krieg in den Städten)/ Steh auf Berlin/ Hirnsäge/ Einsame Wölfin/ Schiess euch ins Blut/ Negativ Nein-Kollaps/ Schwarz/ Für den Untergang.

Photo: Taken from the "Liebeslieder" DVD.

Ticket: Scan of ticket .

Note: Last date of 'Die Berliner Krankheit' tour. "Einsame Wölfin" available on the "So war das S.O.36" V/A VHS video compilation and (partly on) "Liebeslieder" video.

1981

DE Release of the "Live in Berlin 1981" cassette on Eisengrau.

15-Dec-81

DE Berlin-Schöneberg,Metropol (former movie theater @ Nollendorfplatz 5)

[with Schlaflose Nächte]

Setlist: Steh auf Berlin(a.k.a. Krieg in den Städten)/ Skorbut/ Kalte Sterne/ Abstieg & Zerfall-Tanz Debil/ Negativ Nein/ U-Haft Muzak -Hirnsäge/ Kollaps /Durch die Wüste/ Zuckendes Fleisch/ Einsame Wölfin/ Schwarz.

Note: Released on a (Pi+RQ-J6) TapeProduction bootleg cassette. "Durch die Wüste" is a cover of a Ton Steine Scherben song. The band also joins Schlaflose Nächte for a 'jam-session'.

1982

The year in which they tour Europe in January/February for first time. Some scattered live dates later in the year, most notably at the Berlin Atonal festival. Recording and release of the "Durstiges Tier" 12".

1982

DE Release of the "Stahldubversions" cassette album on (Klaus Maeck's) Rip Off label.

17-Jan-82

NL Venlo,OOC

Berlin von Unten

[with Sprung aus den Wolken]

Setlist: Steh auf Berlin(a.k.a. Krieg in den Städten)/ Kollaps/ Skorbut-Schwarz.

Photo: Photo of live cassette taken from cover of "Kassetten" CD (Vol.5 in Musterhaus series).

Article: Scan of article, taken from Trouw 14-Jan-82.

Note: Concert in the early evening. Recorded by the band (but not released).

17-Jan-82

DE Moers,Arrata

[with Rebel Riders & Fettfilme]

Flyer: Xerox of flyer. Year is wrong on flyer.

Note: With Alex von Borsig joining in. Second concert of the day (late evening). Short 25 mins set only.

xx-Jan-82

FR Paris,Musée de la Ville

[with Sprung aus den Wolken]

20-Jan-82

NL Amsterdam,Paradiso

Berlin von Unten

[with Sprung aus den Wolken]

Poster: Scan of a poster designed by Martin Kaye.

Ad: Scan of advert, taken from Volkskrant 14-Jan-82.

Review 1: Scan of review, taken from Trouw 22-Jan-82.

Review 2: Scan of review, taken from Oor 82, courtesy of Dimi.

22-Jan-82

NL Eindhoven,Effenaar

Berlin von Unten

[with Sprung aus den Wolken]

Setlist: Schlangensohn/ Niemandsland/ Jede Wunde ist tief genug/ Tanz Debil/ Wenn ich vor mir selbe kapituliere/ Schwarz/ Sehnsucht/ Steh auf Berlin(a.k.a. Krieg in den Städten)/ Einsame Wölfin/ Kollaps/ U-Haft Muzak/ Nach mir kommt nichts mehr (Atomarer Walzer).

Flyer: Photo of flyer.

Photo: Photo credit Peter Cox, reproduced in "Memories Can't Wait- 40 Years Effenaar" book (2011).

Note: "Schlangensohn" and "U-Haft Muzak" available on the "Live (aufnahmen 07/81 bis 02/82)" cassette album. "Tanz Debil" available on the "Alles was irgendwie nützt" 2CD.

23-Jan-82

NL Nijmegen,Doornroosje

[with Sprung aus den Wolken]

Setlist: a.o. Schatten

Flyer: Xerox of flyer.

Note: Above track available on the "Live (aufnahmen 07/81 bis 02/82)" cassette album.

24-Jan-82

NL Oisterwijk,Vloeiweg,Sneeuwpop festival

[with Sprung aus den Wolken and Rinus De Wildt & Tony]

Setlist: a.o. Einsame Wölfin/ Schwarz

Flyer: Xerox of flyer.

Photo: Photo credit unknown. Sprung aus den Wolken with Alex Hacke (aka Alexander von Borsig).

Note: "Einsame Wölfin" available on the "Live (aufnahmen 07/81 bis 02/82)" cassette album. "Schwarz" available on the "Strategien Against Architecture" album.

Jan-82

DK København?,-

[with Sprung aus den Wolken]

14-Feb-82

DE Aachen,UKW New-Wave disco (@ Rudolfstrasse 44)

[with Frieder Butzmann]

Setlist: Fleisch 'Blut-Haut' Knochen/ Frag mich nicht/ ?/ ?/ ?/ ?/ Schwarz/ Sehnsucht/ U-Haft Muzak.

18-Feb-82

AT Wien,ORF radio station

Note: The day they stole a tape at the ORF radio station and used excerpts on the "Live (aufnahmen 07/81 bis 02/82)" cassette album.

21-Feb-82

AT Linz,Stadtwerkstatt

[with Alexander von Borsig]

Setlist: Fleisch 'Blut/Haut' Knochen/ Halber Mensch/ Abstieg & Zerfall/ Jede Wunde ist tief genug/ Die Sonne/ Der Tod/ Negativ nein/ Schwarz/ Helga (from Kollaps LP)/ Der Winter/ Tanz Debil.

Note: With Alex von Borsig at the mixing desk. "Negativ nein" available on the "Alles was irgendwie nützt" 2CD.

1982

DE Release of the "Live (aufnahmen 07/81 bis 02/82)" cassette album on (Klaus Maeck's) Rip Off label.

29-May-82

DE Berlin-Schöneberg,Risiko bar (@ Yorckstrasse 48)

"Wassermusik" performance

Photo: Screen capture, taken from "Wassermusik" DVD. Another photo, credit Anno Dittmer, taken from "Listen with pain" book by Klaus Maeck.

Note: A Christmas 'performance' (no music) by Blixa Bargeld, N.U. (Andrew) Unruh, Die Tödliche Doris (Nikolaus Utermöhlen, Dagmar Dimitroff and Wolfgang Müller), 3 mermaids (Bettina Scheeder, Brigitta Bauer and Netty) and Alex von Borsig as guest. Basically Wolfgang and Andrew taking a bath (in a plastic tub and metal tub respectively) and the mermaids throwing fish parts. 9mins of footage is available on the "Wassermusik" DVD (Hybriden Verlag 2014). A 1:21mins excerpt released on Tödliche Doris' "Kinderringellreihen.." CD (Psychedelic Pig 2002).

04-Jun-82

NL Amsterdam,Paradiso

(The Birthday Party concert)

Note: At this concert by the Australian band The Birthday Party, Blixa Bargeld is introduced by Gudrun Gut [Malaria!] to singer Nick Cave. Neubauten attends the concert.

04-Jun-82

NL Amsterdam,Huis van Bewaring (@ Kleine-Gartmanplantsoen 14)

[with De Brassers]

Note: At the former house of detention, which closed in 1979.

06-Jun-82

NL Amsterdam,Meervaart

Amsterdam Berlijn -Holland festival

[with Malaria!,Neon Babies, White Russia and Hot Java]

Setlist: Durstiges Tier/ Negativ Nein/ Frisches Blut für Berlin/ Fleisch 'Blut/Haut' Knochen/ Nach mir kommt nichts mehr (Atomarer Walzer)/ Leer-Niemahls/ ?/ Schwarz/ ?

Photo: Screen capture taken from "Liebeslieder" video.

Review: Scan taken from De Waarheid newspaper 08-Jun-82.

Note 1: With Alex von Borsig joining on the 'Durstiges Tier' (a drainpipe) for the first time. Part of the concert was broadcast live-to-air by Dutch VPRO TV. Nick Cave, then touring the Netherlands with The Birthday Party, watches the concert on the TV in the hotel (read more in Nick's article "Thistles In The Soul" as published in his "King Ink I" book). "Durstiges Tier" available on the "2x4" live album. Excerpt available on the "Liebeslieder" video.

Note 2: Malaria! and Neubauten mixed by Mark Reeder [Die Unbekannten].

20-Jun-82

DE Kassel,Kunstbunker

Documenta 7-Art Exhibition

[with Malaria! and Matador]

Setlist: Durstiges Tier/ Fleisch 'Blut/Haut' Knochen/ Der Herrscher und der Sieger/ Asche/ Sehnsucht/ Schlangensohn/ Negativ Nein/ Schwarz.

Photo: Screen capture from film. Great photoset @ Gettyimages/Redferns.

Note: Filmed by Dutch film maker Babeth Van Loo on U-Matic video ("Music-Performances, Documenta 7"). Malaria! and Neubauten mixed by Mark Reeder [Die Unbekannten].

25-Jun-82

NL Amsterdam,Meervaart - Berlin '82 festival

[with MDK, Malaria and Futurologischer Congress]

Ad: Scan of ad, taken from De Waarheid newspaper 24-Jun-82.

Review: Scan of review, taken from De Volkskrant 28-Jun-82.

Note: First concert of the day. Festival recorded and partially broadcast by Dutch KRO FM radio, Rocktempel program.

25-Jun-82

NL Amsterdam,Theater De Balie (@ Kleine Gartmanplantsoen 10)

Setlist: Zuckendes Fleisch/ Schlangensohn/ ?/?/?/?/ Kollaps/ Schwarz/ ?/ Tanz Debil/ Leben ist Illegal/ Sehnsucht.

Note: Second concert of the day. Security intervened when a powerdrill was used on the expensive theatre floor.

24-Sep-82

DE Berlin-Friedenau,Music Hall

(early show)

[with Alexander von Borsig]

Setlist: Sehnsucht/ Warten auf die Zeit (a.k.a. Tanz Debil)/ Asche/ U-Haft Muzak/ Schwarz/ Durstiges Tier/ ?/ Kollaps.

Note: Released on a (Pi+RQ-J6) TapeProduction bootleg cassette. Due to contractual reasons (i.e. they had a second show at the Sector, the same night) the band were billed as "Blixa Bargeld und Freunde".

24-Sep-82

DE Berlin-Kreuzberg/Neukölln,Sector

(late show)

Poster: Photo of poster.

Note: Futuristic live venue/disco located at Hasenheide 13. Huge location known in the 60's/70's as Discothek Cheetah and re-opened by new owners in 1982.

10-Oct-82

Dec-82/Jan-83

DE Berlin-Kreuzberg,Game Studio 36 (basement @ Leuschnerdamm 19). Recording 'Armenia" for the "Zeichnungen des Patienten O.T." album.

Photo: Google street view 2022.

Note: Game Studio was opened in 1979 by Jens Tröndle [1.Futurologischer Congress]. Later, up to 2020, the location of art gallery "Group Global 3000". "We had very good speed in Germany, so we did do long sessions overnight locked in the studio. And the speed gave us the tenacity to stay with an idea until we got it right. One time, we were in this tiny cellar studio right beside the Berlin wall for three days working on 'Armenia', trying to get it right and getting so hung up on tiny details. Chris Bohn and Anton Corbijn turned up to interview us for the NME [published 05-Feb-83], and I remember the look of horror on their faces when they opened the cellar door and saw the state of us. It puts you in a weird space when you spend three days underground on speed". Mark Chung from "Conform To Deform - The weird & wonderful world of Some Bizzare", book by Wesley Doyle (Jawbone, 2023).

Mar/Apr-83

UK London,Trident studios, continuation of the recording sessions for the "Zeichnungen des Patienten O.T." album. Engineered by Jon Caffery, with Flood (aka Mark Ellis). Also recording the "Wardrobe" song (which later appeared on the "If you can't please.." V/A compilation album).

Photo: Credit unknown.

Note 1: "Initially, we didn't write any songs or rehearse. At some point, we got a bit bored with that and decided to actually do a rehearsal, but when we turned up at Trident we didn't have a plan. We spent a lot of time building tape loops, because there was no sampling at that point. We wanted to use the sound of a breaking milk bottle as a snare, but to get it in time we had to run the tape loop right across the studio around a pencil. We would cut holes in the tape, especially the big sixteen-track tape, to just see what effect that had. It basically created dropouts, but things were gone in a random way. We had fun. ". Mark Chung from "Conform To Deform - The weird & wonderful world of Some Bizzare", book by Wesley Doyle (Jawbone, 2023).

Note 2: "I put them in [expense studio] Trident, for as long as they needed, and I walked in there one day and they had the multi-track tape out [that costs a lot of money], and they were cutting holes in it. It was total anarchy". Stevo from "Conform To Deform - The weird & wonderful world of Some Bizzare", book by Wesley Doyle (Jawbone, 2023).

Big Brother - New Year Rock Week

[with C-Cat Trance and F-1 Electric]

Setlist: "Concerto for Machinery and Voice"

Article: Credit by Chris Bohn, taken from NME mag 14-Jan-84. Main photos in article credit Kerstin Rodgers.

Handbill: Scan of handbill.

Score: Scan of page 6 (out of 7) of the score courtesy of Jo Mitchell and Mark Chung.

Note 1: An event with the participation of members of Neubauten (all but Andrew). A (non-musical) piece (for concrete mixers, chainsaw, etc..) written by Mark Chung and FM Einheit. The performance is stopped after 21 mins when the destructions get out of hand. This event was 're-enacted' (not by Neubauten) at the ICA on 20-Feb-07 under guidance from Jo Mitchell.

Note 2: "The Concerto for Voices And Machinery at the ICA came about partly because interests within the band had started to diverge. Blixa was a bit tired of construction machinery at the time, but Mufti and I felt we hadn't done it properly yet. With Neubauten, the machinery was more of a side effect, and we thought it would be interesting to expand that and focus just on that side of things. So, we were the driving force behind the concerto. It wasn't billed as a Neubauten show because Blixa didn't want to do it, and we had Genesis and Frank Tovey on vocals. But on the night, Blixa obviously thought, 'Actually this is quite good, I should be part of it', and jumped onstage at the end. I think Stevo jumped onstage too at some point. It was free-for-all.". Mark Chung from "Conform To Deform - The weird & wonderful world of Some Bizzare", book by Wesley Doyle (Jawbone, 2023).

Line-up: FM Einheit, Mark Chung, Alex Hacke, Genesis P.Orridge [Psychic TV], Frank Tovey [Fad Gadget], Gila Moussou [Schlaflose Nächte], Stevo [Some Bizzare records chief] and only near the very end Blixa Bargeld.

Note: Blixa falls unconscious from exhaustion. From Bloody Mannequin Orchestra's blogspot: "In March 1984, the band played a now-notorious show at the 930 club with Einsturzende Neubauten. The show was marred from the start by an unprecedented blizzard which delayed even the soundcheck until 10pm. Also, Einstürzende Neubauten had asked to use BMO's instruments. Einstürzende played a wild set, which included setting the stage on fire and taking a jackhammer to the 9:30's famous center-stage column; but a visibly wasted Blixa also started wrecking BMO's instruments. Einstürzende fled town, claiming they had no money to pay for the damage. Moral of the story, obvious in hindsight: never lend your instruments to German industrial bands that make music by banging on things!". End of their first North American tour.

May-84

DE Berlin,Hansa Ton studios (Köthener Strasse 38), start of the recording sessions for the "Halber Mensch" album and "Yü-Gung" 12". Engineered by Gareth Jones [Fad Gadget/Depeche Mode].

Photo: Taken on 05-Jun-87, credit Petershagen.

Note: "To be fair, Gareth Jones deserves the credit for 'Yü-Gung'. We always liked using other sounds rather than normal instruments, not least because we weren't very good at playing normal instruments. Gareth had a state-of-the-art AMS [AudioFile, one of the first 16-bit hard disk] samplers [...] I think he'd been using it with Depeche Mode, and although 'Yü-Gung' existed previously and we'd been playing it live, the machine rigueur came from him. We had quite a long discussion about that track because Blixa didn't like being made to sing to a machine. The rest of us thought it was great and something we should absolutely do, but Blixa was, 'I can't sing to this, it's too regular!' It ended up as quite a big argument in the band and Gareth had to do what good producers do. In this case, take Blixa for a walk and talk to him. I suspect Gareth got him to give it a genuine try on the basis that he guaranteed it would not be used if he was not happy with the end result. Anyway, when they came back, Blixa sang on it, and everything was cool.". Mark Chung from "Conform To Deform - The weird & wonderful world of Some Bizzare", book by Wesley Doyle (Jawbone, 2023).

Apr/May-85

DE Berlin,Tritonus Tonstudio (@ Schlesische Strasse 31) & Monongo studios (@ Lützowstrasse 20). Continuation of the recording sessions for the "Halber Mensch" album. Engineered by Gareth Jones.

Note:"I happened to be in Berlin when Neubauten were making Halber Mensch. Coincidentally, Sonic Youth were playing at a venue called Sputnik [17-Apr-85]. On the way to the gig, I stopped off at Tritonus Studios, where Neubauten were recording, to speak to Blixa for a piece I was writing for some magazine or other. They were working on the title track, an a-cappella piece that necessitated recording a few different vocalists. They had some great singers from the German alternative scene coming to record their parts, including Ma Gita, who'd played in Abwärts with Mark Chung. When I arrived, she'd already been there for hours and was getting kind of annoyed with the whole process. So I cut my losses and went to see Sonic Youth, and then went back to the studio after the gig, and they were still working on the same part of the same song and had been the whole time. Tritonus wasn't a cheap studio, so you can imagine the cost."

"'Halber Mensch' cost an absolute fortune to make. Gareth Jones was working with them and really enjoying himself. 'Das Schaben', which is a nine-minute extension of Der Tod Ist Ein Dandy', was in many ways the peak of Some Bizzare. It's an incredible piece of music that took a long time to make and cost a lot of money, but the result is extraordinary. Would Neubauten have been able to make 'Halber Mensch' without Stevo? Well, yes, they'd have made something, and it would have been different and equally as strong, but it would not have sounded so fantastic. But then suddenly Neubauten were in massive debt, so they made their next record ['Fünf auf der nach oben offenen Richterskala'] much more quickly and cheaply. Then Stevo could no longer pull that kind of money from the major labels, and, with all the advances gone, suddenly everybody is going hungry and then that's when relationships started to break down between the artists and Some Bizzare." Chris Bohn from "Conform To Deform - The weird & wonderful world of Some Bizzare", book by Wesley Doyle (Jawbone, 2023).

DE Berlin,Tritonus and Hansa Ton studios, start of the recording sessions for the "Fünf auf der nach oben offenen Richterskala" album. Engineered by Gareth Jones.

Note:"[This] was the one album where we actually rehearsed before recording. I think it's our weakest record, but we rented a rehearsal space for two weeks and actually prepared something for the studio. Obviously we knew that normally songs had structure, we just chose not to use it in our music. It was really more that we'd got a bit tired ourselves of doing everything without discernible song structures, and at some point we felt, Why don't we try that? And I know Blixa discovered structure with his lyrics, which kind of meant we needed to have structure in the music as well. But the main reason was, we wanted to do something different than in the past." Marc Chung from "Conform To Deform - The weird & wonderful world of Some Bizzare", book by Wesley Doyle (Jawbone, 2023).

Review: "So, as we stood in the line waiting to get in, the talk was whether the show would be over by the 10 PM noise curfew. We could already hear the band doing soundcheck inside, and the soundcheck wasn't finished until 9 (the doors were supposed to have been opened at 8 PM for a 9 PM show), after which we were quickly let in. The PA played some really loud music for a half hour while there seemed to be some kind of problem with the equipment or the band's set up on the small stage. Finally, at about 9:40 PM the five of them came out on stage as the taped voices of "Halber Mensch" blasted through the speakers. Blixa tried to sing along with it the best he could but the PA wasn't completely co-operative, cutting out, and they stopped several times trying to correct it before just blasting through to another song, their frustration adding to the level of menace already present in the room. By the time they got through "Z.N.S" and launched into "Yu Gung" there was an almost unbearable intense feeling to the room, like a huge black cloud has descended upon the room. Suddenly, at exactly 10 PM, the house lights went on mid-song and the PA was switched off and the band banged away on their metal shopping carts, steel heating ducts and whatever else wasn't electrically dependent until they realized what had happened. Blixa was cursing out the soundman in German (he was their soundman but the club's sound crew had hit the switch) and suddenly we noticed there were cops by the back stage door. The band briefly tried to start another song before somebody from the club stopped them. Suddenly the crowd realized that the show was over and there was a loud collective moaning of boos." From Livejournal.

Note: The initially scheduled concert at Oklahoma for this day was cancelled.

Poster: Photo of poster.

Note: In 1986, after the closing of the punk venue The Hungry Brain, the Graystone soon filled the void as Detroit's main destination for all-ages punk shows. At first managed by Corey Rusk [of Touch and Go records], but quickly handed over to Cary -Scary- Safarian who brought in bands like Die Kreuzen, MDC, The Crucifucks, Bad Brains, Corrosion of Conformity, and many more, for all-ages shows with low ticket prices. Safarian tried keeping the hall under control, protecting it from the cops, the neighbors, the patrons and sometimes the bands. By 1988, the club was falling apart and mismanaged. Not long after an angry drunk smashed the front doors of the hall in with his car, Safarian left the Graystone and it closed for good.

Oct/Dec-86

DE Hamburg-Billstedt,rehearsal studio provided by Peter Zadek.

Note: Rehearsals for the theatreplay/rockmusical "Andi" directed by Peter Zadek, in which the band performs live on stage. The band loathe the play (about a Hamburger youth shot dead by a shop owner), but loves the money they are paid for it.

Despite the fact that the rehearsal space has good recording equipment, in all the time they will spend in Hamburg the band will never record. Instead they live a life a drugs and alcohol enjoying the first time they have loads of money. They frequently fly back to Berlin with the free plane tickets provided by Peter Zadek. For 1.5 years (as long as the play runs) the band would not grow artistically, although they would benefit from performing live so often.

Mark Chung is the only one who would invest the money earned wisely, in the incorporation of Freibank (to administer the copyrights of music artists). During this period FM Einheit's daughter Amanda is born, upon which he decides to move to the countryside in Bayern.

Ad: Taken from Sounds 29-Aug-87.

Ticket: Photo of ticket.

Note 1: First UK performance since 1985 (02-Sep-85). Only UK date of this tour. With Bambi Lee Savage in the audience. Showaddywaddy were a pop band from the 70's dressed as Teddy Boys and covering hits from the 50s.

Note 2: "We had a new album and single coming out, and we wanted to up the ante a little bit. Our promotor [...] came to us saying we'd been offered a gig [...] with Einstürzende Neubauten. I immediately said, 'Who?' I wasn't into goth rock. [...] I knew Stevo was a bit of an oddball, and he'd obviously got this idea for the most incongruous matchup of artists he could possibly find. I actually spoke to him and got the feeling he was looking to embarrass us, in a sense. But we agreed to do it, and from the word go it was obvious that we were the seen as the support band, and consequently were treated as such. There were issues with dressing rooms, our rider hadn't been adhered to in any way [...] and to put it bluntly, we were treated like shit. We were definitely the underdogs, [...] so we rose to the challenge and really kicked it out. It had the desired effect, and we proceeded to go down a storm. It was quite extraordinary to see that crowd reacting to it. The icing on the cake was, we watched Neubauten's performance -out of curiosity, more than anything- they couldn't follow us. We literally blew them off the stage. I spoke to a few journalists afterward, and they were handing out the plaudits, saying they didn't expect us to be that good. [...] Years later Time Out listed it at number 56 in their list of '100 Greatest London Gigs Of All Time'!" Dave Bartram [Showaddywaddy] from "Conform To Deform - The weird & wonderful world of Some Bizzare", book by Wesley Doyle (Jawbone, 2023).

1989

The year in which they only do a handful (6) of performances in the first half. Finalisation and release of the "Haus der Lüge" album followed by a (29 dates) long European tour between September/December.

Jan/May-89

DE Berlin,Hansa and Tritonus and Preussenton studios, finalization of the recording sessions (started in May 1988) for the "Haus der Lüge" album and "Feurio!" single. "Prolog" engineered by Raymond 'Pig' Watts, rest by Jon Caffery. Some tracks are recorded at Ton Steine Scherben's studio in Fresenhagen (Nordfriesland). "Schwindel" is concocted by Blixa and Andrew at the last minute to make the album longer than only 30 mins. Mixed in one go by Jon Caffery.
